item.title: Session 4: Homework 2
item.description: Climate change and temperature anomalies #Loading data weather <- read_csv("https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/tabledata_v4/NH.Ts+dSST.csv", skip = 1, na = "***") #skipping the missing data Select the year and the twelve month variables from the weather dataset. #Select the data we need weather_data <- weather %>% select(Year, Jan:Dec) Convert the dataframe from wide to ‘long’ format. #Convert data into long format #Names of the columns Jan-Dec will become values of new column "Month" #Monthly temperature deviations stored in column "delta" tidyweather <- weather_data %>% pivot_longer(cols=c("Jan","Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"), names_to="Month", values_to="delta") glimpse(tidyweather) #preview tidied dataset ## Rows: 1,704 ## Columns: 3 ## $ Year <dbl> 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880~ ## $ Month <chr> "Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "~ ## $ delta <dbl> -0.

item.title: About me
item.description: Biography Hi, my name is Jelena Savic and I’m a current LBS student. I was born in 1996 in Belgrade, Serbia. I graduated from School of Electrical Engineering, University of Belgrade, and started my career working in the IT industry. After a year, I decided to make a shift to the world of Business and Finance. Master in Analytics and Management seamed as an ideal option, and after extensive preparation, I was accepted to her dream school.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.
